questions.question:
Question 1: The principle that “ In spinal cords, dorsal roots are sensory and ventral roots are motor” is 
known as
questions.explanation:
The principle that in the spinal cord the dorsal roots are sensory and the ventral roots are motor is 
known as the Bell–Magendie law. Laws in Sensory Physiology • Muller's doctrine of specific nerve energies: When the nerve pathways from a particular sense 
organ are stimulated, the sensation evoked is that for which the receptor is specialized, no matter 
how or where along the pathway the activity is initiated. 231 
Sold by @itachibot • Law of projection: No matter where a particular sensory pathway is stimulated along its course 
to the cortex, the conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of the receptor. • Weber-Fechner Law: Magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the log of the 
intensity of the stimulus. • Labelled line theory: All the sensations from the different parts of the body travel along specified 
paths. For example, in the posterior column, fibers from the lower parts of the body are placed 
medially.

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient admitted to the ward does not feel a sensation of the heat on touching a hot object. 
Considering the signal reaches the thalamus, which of the following is not transmitting the 
signal to an intact postcentral gyrus?
questions.explanation:
In this scenario, the tertiary neuron does not transmit the signal to the postcentral gyrus. In the thalamus, secondary sensory neurons synapse onto tertiary sensory neurons, which in turn 
project to the somatosensory region of the cerebral cortex. The question tests your knowledge of this pathway. It is said that the signal reaches the thalamus 
and the postcentral gyrus is intact. Still, the person cannot perceive the sensation, so the pathway 
is broken between the thalamus and the gyrus, which has to be at the tertiary neuron.

questions.question: Question 3: Decussation of ascending spinal pathways occurs mainly within the
questions.explanation:
Decussation of ascending spinal pathways occurs mainly within the spinal cord and medulla 
oblongata. Most of the ascending pathways and tracts do decussate or cross; however, some 
remain uncrossed. Dorsal column pathway crosses in the medulla oblongata. The anterior and lateral spinothalamic tract crosses obliquely in the spinal segments. 232 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: Conscious proprioception is carried by

questions.explanation:
Conscious proprioception is carried by dorsal column. Unconscious proprioception is carried by 
spinocerebellar tract. Option B and C: Anterolateral system carries pain, temperature, crude touch.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not a property of fibers in the dorsal column pathway?
questions.explanation:
The dorsal column–medial lemniscal system is composed of large, myelinated nerve fibers and 
thus transmit signals to the brain, at high velocities of 30 to 110 m/sec. Option B: Dorsal column carries fine touch and anterolateral column carries crude touch 233 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient comes to you for his annual health checkup. He lost his vision due to an accident a 
few years ago. He now experiences the world through touch. Which of the following 
Brodmann’s areas processes this tactile stimulation?
questions.explanation:
Processing of tactile stimulation occurs in Brodmann’s area in 3, 1, 2. The human cerebral cortex is divided into about 50 distinct areas called Brodmann’s areas based 
on histological structural differences. Areas 3, 1, 2 which constitute primary somatosensory area I, and areas 5 and 7, which constitute 
the somatosensory association area process sensory information like tactile stimulation.

questions.question: Question 7: Cortical representation of body in the cerebrum is
questions.explanation:
Cortical representation of body in the cerebrum is vertical. Parts of the body are represented in order along the postcentral gyrus, with the legs on top and 
head at the bottom of the gyrus. A cortical homunculus is a distorted representation of the human body, based on a neurological 
map of the areas and proportions of the human brain dedicated to processing motor functions, or 
sensory functions, for different parts of the body. The size of the cortical receiving area for 
impulses from a particular part of the body is proportionate to the use of the part. Sensory Homunculus is a topographical representation of distribution of sensory input to the 
somatosensory cortex from different parts of the body. Motor homunculus is a topographical representation of distribution of motor output from primary 
motor cortex to different parts of the body. Sensory homunculus is depicted below: 234 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: Somatosensory area has the largest representation for 226 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Somatosensory area has the largest representation for lips. The relative sizes of the cortical receiving areas of the sensory homunculus are proportionate to 
the use of the part. The sizes of these areas are directly proportional to the number of specialized 
sensory receptors in each respective peripheral area of the body. Some body parts are represented by large areas in the somatic cortex—the lips the greatest of all, 
followed by the face and thumb, whereas the trunk and lower part of the body are represented by 
relatively small areas.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient sustains an injury to the lateral portion of the postcentral gyrus in the right 
hemisphere. Loss of sensation is likely to be seen at which of the following sites in this 
patient?
questions.explanation:
In this case, injury to the lateral portion of the postcentral gyrus in the right hemisphere would 
result in loss of sensation in the left facial area. Each hemisphere receives somatic sensory information from the opposite side of the body in the 
postcentral gyrus (somatosensory area). The lateral portion of the postcentral gyrus receives somatic sensory information from the facial 
and neck region while the medial portion of the postcentral gyrus received somatic sensory 
information from the trunk and appendages. 235 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: Lesion of somatosensory area I affects
questions.explanation:
Lesion of the somatosensory area I affects the localization of sensations. Bilateral lesion of the somatosensory area I leads to the following impairment of sensory 
judgment: • Inability to localize different sensations in different parts of the body • Inability to judge degrees of pressure against the body • Inability to judge the weight of the objects • Inability to judge shapes of forms of objects - astereognosis • Inability to judge the texture of the materials Pain and temperature are not affected both in quality and intensity in the lesion of the 
somatosensory area I. However, they are poorly localised. Pain and temperature localization 
depends greatly on the topographical map of the body in somatosensory area I to localize the 
source.`

questions.question:
Question 11: A man was rushed to the casualty after getting stabbed in the back with a knife. On MRI, a 
complete transection of one side of the spinal cord is suspected. Which of the following is 
likely to be seen in this patient?

options.a: Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
options.b: Fine touch lost on the opposite side
options.c: Pain and temperature lost on the same side
options.d: Only pain lost on the same side

questions.explanation:
This patient most likely has Brown-Sequard syndrome. It is characterized by loss of pain and 
temperature on the opposite side. Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, 
ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is 
called the Brown-Séquard syndrome. The lesion to fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus leads to ipsilateral loss of discriminative 
touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion. 236 
Sold by @itachibot The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation 
beginning one or two segments below the lesion. Damage to the corticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups on 
the same side of the body.

questions.question:
Question 12: 227 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following findings are seen in a patient with Brown-Sequard syndrome?

options.a: Upper Motor Neuron type of paralysis below the lesion on the opposite side
options.b: Impaired fine touch below the lesion on the opposite side
options.c: Loss of crude touch below the lesion on the same side
options.d: Loss of vibration sense below the lesion on the same side

questions.explanation:
A patient with Brown Sequard syndrome will have a loss of vibration sense below the lesion on the 
same side. Brown-sequard syndrome is caused due to hemisection of the Spinal cord. It can be caused by 
fracture-dislocation of the vertebral column, by a bullet or stab wound, or by an expanding tumor. Clinical features: • Pyramidal tract: Pyramidal weakness (ipsilateral upper motor neuron type of paralysis) below 
the level of the lesion on the same side as the lesion (pyramidal tract crosses in the medulla). • Dorsal columns: Impaired fine touch, 2 point discrimination, proprioception, vibration below 
the level of lesion on the same side of lesion (dorsal column fibres cross in the medulla). • Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain, temperature, crude touch, pressure sensation below the level 
of the lesion on the contralateral side of the lesion (spinothalamic tract crosses midline after 
entering the cord).

questions.question: Question 13: Itch is carried by
questions.explanation:
Itch-specific fibers have been demonstrated in the anterolateral spinothalamic tract. They are 
carried by unmyelinated nerve fiber C. Itching can be produced by repeated local mechanical 
stimulation of skin, variety of chemical agents including histamine and kinins released in the skin 
in response to tissue damage Simple scratching relieves itching because it activates large fast conducting afferents (A) that gate 
the transmission in the dorsal horn in a manner analogous to inhibition of pain by stimulation of 
similar afferents (Gate control theory).

questions.question: Question 14: Following are the endogenous opioids except
questions.explanation:
Endogenous opioids, a group of neuropeptides that includes 
beta-endorphin, dynorphins, and enkephalins. Opioids cause both presynaptic and post synaptic inhibition reducing excitatory post-synaptic 
potential (EPSP). Opioids are released from the descending analgesic pathway and bind with 
opiate receptors on the afferent pain-fiber terminal. This binding suppresses the release of 
substance P, blocking further transmission of the pain signal. 237 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: You are examining a patient for a follow-up of severe pain in his right leg. He tells you that he 
feels much better now that he is taking acupuncture therapy too. Which of the following is 
responsible for pain relief in acupuncture?
questions.explanation:
Pain relief in acupuncture is by the release of endorphin. The acupuncture endorphin hypothesis is the primary mechanism of acupuncture analgesia. 
According to this hypothesis, Acupuncture is thought to activate afferent neurons leading to spinal 
cord and midbrain centers that release endogenous opioids implicated in pain relief.

questions.question:
Question 16: 228 
Sold by @itachibot Fast pain is carried by
questions.explanation: Fast pain is carried by neospinothalamic tract. Pain signals take two pathways to the brain: • Neospinothalmic tract for fast pain/epicritic pain (A fibres) • Paleospinothalamic tract for slow pain/Protopathic pain (C fibres)

questions.question:
Question 17: Soldiers wounded in the heat of battle often feel no pain until the battle is over which is an 
example of stress-induced analgesia. This is due to
questions.explanation: Stress induced analgesia is due to cannabinoids. The stress-induced analgesia, i.e., reduced pain sensitivity during stressful events might be due to: • Release of endogenous cannabinoids such as 2-arachidonoylglycerol (2-AG) and anandamide • Release of Norepinephrine from brainstem catecholaminergic neurons in the amygdala.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following does not carry proprioceptive impulses?
questions.explanation:
Tectocerebellar tract does not carry proprioceptive impluses. Tectocerebellar tract carry visual and 
auditory impulses. Spinocerebellar, olivo cerebellar, cuneo cerebellar tracts carry Proprioceptive impulses. Vestibulocerebellar tract carry vestibular impulses.

questions.question: Question 19: Pain and temperature in the thalamus are controlled by which of the following nuclei?
questions.explanation:
Pain and temperature in thalamus are controlled by the ventral posterior lateral nucleus. Pain and 
temperature is carried by anterolateral spinothalamic tract. Fibres from anterolateral spinothalamic tract and dorsal column synapse in the ventral 
posteriorlateral (VPL) nucleus of thalamus. 238 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: The pathway from taste receptors includes synapses in the nucleus of the tractus 
solitarius in the brainstem and ventral posterior medial nucleus in the thalamus. Option C: Anterior nucleus functions as a relay station for the hippocampal impulses. It receives 
afferents from mammillothalamic tract. It sends efferents to cingulate gyrus. Option D: Intralaminar nucleus participates in arousal reaction, it recieves afferents from reticular 
formation of brain stem.

questions.question:
Question 20: 229 
Sold by @itachibot Ventrolateral cordotomy for relief of pain in the right lower limb is being performed on a 
patient. Which of the following is cut in this procedure?
questions.explanation:
In ventrolateral cordotomy, selected pain-conducting tracts in the spinal cord, i.e. fibers in the 
lateral spinothalamic pathway, are cut leading to contralateral loss of pain and temperature 
sensation below the level of the lesion. In the more recent percutaneous approach, destruction of the lateral spinothalamic at the level of 
C1-C2 results in a contralateral disruption of painful sensations beyond C4. Note: The fibers carrying pain sensation ascend in the lateral spinothalamic tract while the fibers 
carrying crude touch and pressure sensations ascend in the anterior spinothalamic tract.

questions.question: Question 21: Pick the correct statement:

options.a: Spinal lemniscus carries fibres of dorsal spinothalamic tract
options.b: Trigeminal lemniscus carries pain and temperature sensations from the ipsilateral orofacial
options.c: Lateral lemniscus carries fibres from cochlear nuclei
options.d: Medial lemniscus carries fibres from of vestibular nuclei

questions.explanation:
Lateral lemniscus carries fibres from cochlear nuclei Medial lemniscus carries fibres from of dorsal column nuclei Spinal lemniscus carries fibres of anterolateral spinothalamic tract Trigeminal lemniscus carries pain and temperature sensations from the contralateral orofacial 
region 239

questions.question: Question 22: Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes which of the following?

options.a: Pain and temperature loss in the same side
options.b: Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side
options.c: Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side
options.d: Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

questions.explanation:
Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes loss of tactile and proprioception on the 
opposite side. Fibers of medial lemniscus ascend ipsilaterally in the dorsal columns of the spinal cord to the 
medulla, where they synapse in the gracilus and cuneate nuclei. The second-order neurons from these nuclei cross the midline and ascend in the medial lemniscus 
to end in the contralateral ventral posterior lateral (VPL) nucleus and related specific sensory 
relay nuclei of the thalamus.

questions.question: Question 23: Ablation of somatosensory area 1 leads to

options.a: Macula lutea is the blind spot
options.b: low density of photoreceptors are present in macula

questions.explanation:
Ablation of somatosensory area 1 leads to Loss of tactile and 2 point discrimination. Widespread bilateral excision of the somatosensory area I causes loss of the following types of 
sensory judgment: • The person is unable to localize discretely the different sensations in the different parts of the 
body. However, he or she can localize these sensations crudely, such as to a particular hand. The 
brain stem, thalamus, or parts of the cerebral cortex can perform some degree of localization. • The person is unable to judge critical degrees of pressure/weight/texture. 240 
Sold by @itachibot Special Senses
